comments.text:
+XBlueM0ndayX The quote fits quite well I think. It is not so much that pot 
itself is an essential liberty, but rather our right to choose what we 
ingest and take the responsibility for it, assuming it is no detriment to 
others, that ought to be an essential liberty. One which you would take 
away for the sake of security, a security which is clearly imaginary since 
none of your points hold any legitimacy anyway. Such as the vapid 
insinuation that people are safer concealing it illegally at home (*rolls 
eyes* because people definitely don't smoke pot outside of home because 
it's illegal! Kids definitely don't do it at school, all the time...), and 
then travelling to drug dealers who no doubt deal with a bunch of other 
drugs, many of which are legitimately life destroying. Yes, that situation 
positively glows with security. 

"alcohol is heavily regulated even though it's legal, is that giving up an 
essential liberty?"

It is technically sacrificing some degree of freedom, but not nearly to the 
same extent as having alcohol banned altogether, no? And those regulations 
are to prevent cases where the harm it causes is incontrovertible, like 
letting people drink & drive... no one can argue that isn't going to result 
in accidents. By contrast your arguments about pot causing harm seem 
insipid & uninspired.

Also the claim that pot has no health benefits is demonstrably a load of 
shit. You do know many thousands of people have permits to use marijuana 
for medicinal purposes, right? It's been used for thousands of years that 
way too. 

You seem like you're arguing against a strawman though - I never once 
implied Marijuana should be completely unregulated & that people should be 
able to smoke it in bars and then drive home, or anything remotely similar.
comments.author: Vire70

comments.text:
+Vire70 Quoting Benjamin Franklin to me in an argument about accepted pot 
use? Really? If you ever try to tell me pot use is an "essential liberty" 
up there with freedom of speech and the right to vote, you're a massive 
idiot. To point out the fallacy of your quote to you as well: alcohol is 
heavily regulated even though it's legal, is that giving up an essential 
liberty?

I couldn't care less if both liquor and cigarettes were outlawed. I don't 
use either. So your 'hypocrisy' argument can suck it. Problem is alcohol 
has become so ingrained in modern society that as soon as you try to outlaw 
it people will immediately turn to criminal means to obtain it. No matter 
how prevalent marijuana use is, it certainly doesn't rival alcohol yet. And 
because it doesn't actually have any health benefits, why legalise it? A 
lot of problems we have with cigarettes and alcohol abuse now would have 
been lessened had they never been legalised, but here we go taking the same 
route with pot.

I'm not worried about everyone in society turning into pot users either, 
that's not going to happen. Most people will just not use it cause they 
don't want to. But with legalisation comes a change in its accepted use in 
society. While pot is unlawful at least people have to be careful about 
where they smoke it, and arguably that prevents them from putting 
themselves in more dangerous situations (like driving to a bar, getting 
stoned, then driving home).

Finally, I don't think you should hold everyone's hand in life either. Let 
stupid people make stupid decisions that put themselves at risk. But 
letting people go out into the world (rather than their own homes) to get 
stoned and then interact with others while they're in an altered state of 
consciousness is a recipe for disaster in terms of other people getting 
hurt. There's enough to look out for already, why make the list of accepted 
but damaging public behaviours longer?

And to Delta9: I'm no moron. If you can't bear to hear another side 
different to the stance you're vehemently loyal to, sit down and shut up.
comments.author: XBlueM0ndayX

liberty to purchase a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor

You cannot hold everyones hand in life. It is not the governments 
responsibility to stop people making poor decisions. The only case in which 
pot should be illegal, as is the case with alcohol & cigarettes, is when it 
affects others - for alcohol that is driving or for public disorder, for 
cigarettes there are bans on it in public places due to second hand smoke. 
Similar stipulations for pot would be fine, including making it illegal to 
smoke in public places (or obviously driving under its influence). Making 
it illegal, as it is now, to smoke in private at home is simply 
indefensible and your reasons don't apply to that at all. You want a 
blanket ban on something because some proportion of people are idiots. 
Well, I think you're just as dumb as they are if you really believe that's 
a legitimate argument. 

I mean your entire argument rests upon the premise that a lot more people 
are going to get pot if it becomes legal, when the reality is that anyone 
who is going to use it frequently or abuse it, almost certainly already has 
access to it. Making it illegal doesn't stop people from doing it, it 
merely makes them secretive and encourages criminal exploitation. 

Maybe a vendor will have to pay tax, but what stops people from growing pot 
themselves if it's legal? Very little. Zero exploitation possible, criminal 
enterprises will vanish, govt will still earn plenty of money selling it to 
those who aren't interested in growing it themselves, and if it is harmful 
to anyone it will be far less so than alcohol or tobacco. I've made the 
same statement before I think, but again; anyone who argues that marijuana 
should be illegal is engaging in illogical hypocrisy unless they're also 
campaigning to have alcohol & tobacco banned. You cannot argue for one and 
ignore the other without being a total hypocrite.

psychological level as in we're very fond of the feel and stimulation it 
provides. Persons who smoke daily should be the first to realize this. 
There's not many physical things that can make people repeat the same 
activity 5 times per day and look forward to the next unless there's some 
kind of chemical reward. The irony of it is that most daily smokers +Jerb 
Wood don't realize this. I dropped this argument cuz it's about to be a 
shitstorm of legalization supporters bashing in their arguments of 
government control, and fluoride in the water. stfu +habadashery2009
comments.author: VanillaSnake21

comments.text:
+VanillaSnake21 mj is less harmful than coffee or even aspirin. you CANNOT 
die from pot. PERIOD! ive even tried to smoke to death just for fun. NOT 
POSSIBLE! fuck the government. whether it is legal or not, free americans 
will smoke no matter what they say. its legal to me already i will smoke

comments.text:
What would forcing people who don't have medical problems to get a 
prescription do? Do you just want to increase medical costs exponentially 
for no reason? 

If alcohol doesn't need a prescription to use recreationally then why 
should marijuana be any different? Especially considering marijuana is 
infinitely safer than alcohol, isn't addictive, and doesn't cause any 
health problems.
comments.author: habadashery2009

comments.text:
If you have to have a prescription for Marijuana than you should have to 
get a prescription for alcohol. Do you agree?
comments.author: Jerb Wood

comments.text:
No prescriptions! How can I be anymore clear about this? Regulated and 
legalized for adults over the age of 21. What is the point of getting a 
prescription for something that you can't even overdose from? seriously, do 
you not get it?
comments.author: Jerb Wood

comments.text:
+Jerb Wood But you do agree that it should be regulated, so it should not 
be sold to everyone, otherwise as I said it's impossible to regulate it. So 
if they fully legalize the current system of dispensaries and perscription, 
and do it on a federal level, that would be exactly what you're talking 
about, it will be regulated and almost anyone will be able to get it if 
they're willing to go for a prescription.
comments.author: VanillaSnake21

comments.text:
That sounds like something a dictator would say. People can take care of 
themselves. They've been doing it for hundreds of years. We don't need to 
be coddled. The FDA only cares about one thing now. MONEY! they do not care 
about what is good or bad for us. A prescription is unnecessary for 
something that grows naturally. The last thing I want is a pharmaceutical 
company being the only ones to grow Marijuana. There is nothing that can be 
done to even get it to that point because no matter what, there's always 
going to be people that grow weed without consent from the government. Yes 
I want it to be regulated, but I do not want the government or fda having 
complete control over it.
comments.author: Jerb Wood

comments.text:
+Jerb Wood Letting people control what they want is dangerous. This nerfing 
you speak about is necessary so that drug epidemics don't start. I'm not 
saying the weaker drugs like mj or acid can cause epidemics but it is 
useful to limit what people want for their own benefit. Secondly you seem 
to want to get it regulated so you know the source, then passing it through 
FDA will get that, it will get you the most purest, perfectly grown bud 
with estimaded mg dosage of each so you know exactly how much you're 
smoking. It's a win-win for all, all you need is a prescription, and you 
will get the best weed.
comments.author: VanillaSnake21

comments.text:
We'll all be tripping in 100 years? Give the human race a little more 
credit. lsd, peyote, ayahuasca are all completely different drugs that have 
completely different effects. If this is your logic than alcohol should 
also be illegal for the effects it has on human beings. Nerfing the world 
is a stupid thing to do. If people want to do any of these drugs than they 
will find a way to do it regardless of it is legal or not. Putting 
restrictions on everything only leads to more money for criminals and the 
black market. I would much rather have people buying drugs that are 
regulated than have them buy from some random person on the street where 
they don't know what is in it or where it came from. Like I said, Americans 
should have a choice to do what they want, when they want. if they decide 
to be stupid and harm others than they will face the consequences. But 
making Marijuana illegal or enacting harsh penalties and fines just for 
possession is ridiculous.
comments.author: Jerb Wood

comments.text:
+Jerb Wood It doesn't matter where the thc is sored, once it's realeased 
from the fat cells they still end up in your bloodstream, it's like a slow 
delivery system. It's obvious that you are the one who does not know. So to 
you from your own perspective it would seem like it has not affected your 
reflexes, concentration etc. If you had fast reflexes to begin with then 
you might not even notice it. But it was shown through many studies that 
the general cognitive state is somewhat lower in daily smokers. Some can 
drive while intoxicated as well, so you're saying we should not stop them 
just because they know how to handle it? But you're missing the point, as 
you said those who do it should face legal consequences just like alcohol. 
At the bottom of this is whether we should allow another drug that is hard 
to test for, to be sold publicly in shops. I've said I'm for legalization, 
in the same way like other drugs are legal. By going through a presciber. 
It seems to be pretty easy to get anyways from what I heard, most just go 
in and say they have insomnia or anxiety. Otherwise if we keep going down 
this path we will eventually get to lsd, peyote, ayuhasca which are even 
safer then mj. In 100 years we're all going to be tripping balls from an 
early age XD
comments.author: VanillaSnake21

comments.text:
+VanillaSnake21 You obviously do not know what you are talking about. THC 
stores in your fat cells. Just because it is "stored up" there does not 
make the affect of your next smoke greater. In fact it does not have any 
affect on you whatsoever. " If you're a daily smoker you still get the side 
effects of weed, even more so since it's built up in your system"?? That is 
one of the most false statements I have ever heard. You are speaking to 
someone who has smoked pot everyday for nearly 10 years. I am healthier 
than most. I have been to the doctor at least twice a year since I was 16 
years old and I have never told them I am a smoker. They cannot even tell 
that I am one. and if they do know they are not saying anything to me about 
it. I have first hand knowledge of what marijuana does. I have driven on 
many occasions to many places high and have never had any issues with depth 
perception or cognitive skills. Don't get me wrong, someone who is not used 
to marijuana should never get behind the wheel. But for someone who is a 
regular, experienced smoker, it does not affect them in a way that makes 
them harmful. Please do some research on the subject before you go making 
bold claims about what Marijuana does and doesn't do. Because as of now I 
don't believe you have the knowledge to tell anyone about the safety or 
danger of it.
comments.author: Jerb Wood

comments.text:
So you'd rather criminals run an industry rather than there being 
reasonable regulations like we have with alcohol? Why do you think 
legalization would result in people driving while high? You realize 
everyone who wants weed can get it right now right? The only difference is 
criminals are the ones selling it instead of reputable growers and dealers.

top_comment.text:
I used to weigh 268 pounds at the height of 5'10 1/2.
When I began smoking I became more social and active.
Over time I dropped weight, and now am 150 at 5'10 1/2.
I think I need to gain some weight back personally.
But when people say that smoking marijuana gives you weight it is a crock, 
I see my weight scale drop like a cliff then begin to slowly go down before 
hitting my current weight and flat-lining then laugh at how people blame 
marijuana. THC does give you a craving for food, if your new to it. If you 
do over eat on it, then of course you will gain some type of weight. I 
believe that would of been common knowledge.﻿
top_comment.author: Lazy Productions
